1t becomes our mournfu duty to record the death
of the Right Reverend JAMES KEMP, d. D. late
Bishop Of The Protestant Episcopal Church in MARY.
land. and Provost of the University of MARYLAND.
who departed th, life yesterday at about quarter
past o'clock. z. NJ The meekness with which this
distinguished divine bore his high faculties, had en-
deared him in peculiar manner to those whom Pro.
vidence had placed under bis pastoral charse.wlilst
his uniformly unassuming department, and upright
conduct rendered him the object ofprofound respect
on the part Of those with whom he acted in the gen.
eral intercourse of life. As the head of the Church
which he called to preside in this Diocese,
his loss will be long and deeply lalnented-as pr-
vate individual, those who were bound to him by the
closest ties of relationship and friendship, cam
alone form estimate Of the extent OF their beveav
ement.


The circumstances attending the death of this
estinabie and distinguished individual are such as
to render particular distressing. AS he was reur-
ming from Philade pha, where I've had been to assist
in the conservation of Bishop Onderdonk,in passing
over the Peninsula between the two bays the driver
of the coach in which he was, being intoxicated as
is supposed. attempted to pass another carriage and
upset the coach, by which means several OF the pas
sensers were severely injured, and among Others
Bishop KEMP received the hurt, which has terminal
ed in his death.


Scarcely day passes that we do not hear some
new account OF the outrageous conduct Of Coach
men, and their careless driving. 1t is high time
that the strong arm Of the law should interpose, aud
punish in an exemplary manner these offenders
against public safety.

The following is extract of letter addressed
to the editor Of the Argus, containing statement Of
The late bloody affair, near Natchez, by party
from Alexandria, via Eapde =


Concordia, Sept. "a, 1927,


Dear Sir 81 was invited by Dr. Maddox. not
long since, to interview without the limits Of the
State. met him at Natchez, on the 18th instant


on the 18th, was challenged by him. appointed
the 9th for the day, and the first sand beach above
Natchez, on the Mississippi side, for the place o.
our meeting. We met exchanged two shots with
out effect, and made friends. Myself and my tnenq'
Major NV Whortcr, and my surgeon DR.. Cuney,
were invited by DR.. Maddox and his friend, Col
Crane, and surgeon, Mr. Denny, to the Wooas'
where his friends, who were excluded from the
held, were stationed, to take some refreshment
when about half way, we were met by my irenas,
Gen. Cuney, Mr.. James Bowie, and my brother VINO
had accompanied me from Red River, and VINO
were also excluded from the field, and had taken
their station in the woods about two huadrec yaros
from the field. Gen. Quincy, on meeting us. enqur.
ed of me how the affair had been settled toa
him that Dir. Maddox and myself had exchanged
two shots and made friends Eic then turned to Col.
Crane who was near me, and observed to hun, lhas
there was difference between them, and they l@a
better return to the ground and settle it. as Docof
Maddox and myself had done DR.. Cuney ana my,
self nerposed, and stated to the General, tha ha'
not the time place ior the adjustment OF lheli
difference the General ilnnediatey acqmesceo
and his brother had turned to leave him, wheh
Crane, without replying to Gen. Cuney, or sayilS
one word, 1red pistol at him, which ne cari'eu
in his hand, but without effect. then steppeu
back one OF two PAGES, when Crane drew from ND >
belt another pistol, fred it and wounded Geneiai
Cuney in his thigh he expired in about fifteen nm
utes. As Crane presented his second pistol, uen.
Cuney placed his hand upon the breach OF his pu;
did not draw until he had received Cranes second
fire, and as he was falling. Gen, Cuney did nos
will state on the authority of DR.. Hunt. of Natchez


that Crane had said to his friends in Natchez' tha


# Gen Quincy made his appearance on the ground
he, Crane, would kill hm-and that at all events
he intended to kill him the first opportunity-ano
we'll has he kept his promise Mr.. Denny has slne'
informed me that Crane had made the same dee'S

From The Eihion Press.

1t will be gratifying the friends Of freedom to
learn that the people Of coloy held by the society Of
Friends in North Carolina, are all in fair way to
be placed in free governments. Since the number
sent out last year, the meeting has received donations
from this continent, to the amount Of nearly fys
thousand dollars, in addition to two Thousand dol
lars raised by themselves. We also learn that q
draft to considerable amount has been received
from they early Meeting of the Society Of Friends
in London. to assist them in the noble undertaking.
The present prospect is, that in the course Of year
or two more, 6etWeen one and f1co thousand persons
will be placed in situation to enjoy their unaena-
ole righs We understand that the principal part
Of them will go to Africa and st. Domingo.

The extraordinary measures of Gen. Jackson
during the continuance Of the Seminole war; not
only elected deep and loud complaints from the

subject was broush before the House Of Represen-

constitutional restraint, with degree Of boldness |
and eoqaence which even surpassed all his prevlcas
efforts.


The Generals conduct was also made subject
of inquiry in the Senate. In this investigation Mr.
Leacock and Roberts, of this state. and Mr.. Eppes,
Of Va. took an active part The GeNeral COM

usual profanity, that he would chastise him in the
midst Of the body in which his injurious remarks
had been made. This report reached the Of
the gallant Decatur. lie considered it, however,
as Of those idle declarations which men Of intem-
perae passions not unfrequently make, without any
intention of putting into execution.

MANUFACTURES IN THE SOUTH.
Tie capacity of the Southern states for manufac-
turing their great staple is no longer IA matter OF
speculation. Practical experiment has demonstrated,
not only their capacity TO manufacture, but to man
ufacture their own staple at cheaper rate than IN
any part of the Union Last February. year,
accompanied most intelligent Tennessee planter
from Ptisburg to Nashville, Mr.. Nightingale, Tor
merly of Rhode Island. He was then taking with
him .foreman', from Providence, Rhode island, to
superntend his cotton factory. This factory IS To-
Gated in Maury county, Tennessee. The machine
ry is propelled by never failing. and never fseez,
ing water power. The entire abour is performed
BY slaves. Mr. Nightingale now supplies a large
portion OF Tennessee and North Alabama with coarse
cotton goods. His profits upon his capital are said
to be quadrupe the profits Of the cotton grower.
What, then, but enterprise, is wanting to Introduce
the manufacture of cotton. largely the Southern
states, from Maryland to Loulsiana-for the follow
III. reasons


LIST. he capacity of the slave to manufacture
is demonstrated by the test Of practical expert
nent.


Cd. The superior cheapness of slave labour is
also evident. to anv one who will reflect, that the
price of boy, or girl, sufficiently large 10 draV the
Nread. can be procured in Maryland, Virginia or
kentu,ky, for 5000

abandonment uf he tartor, BY any of the hands, no
fiuc;uat!on in the lab ,ur. The water power will
scarcely be more steady than the slave pow
err


4. The superior mildness Of the climate. not
only facilitates the operation of the spindle and
the loom, but arrests hand of winter which
binds the Northern water power IN letters o
ice.

1t becomes our mournfu duty to record the death
of the Right Reverend JAMES KEMP, d. D. late
Bishop Of The Protestant Episcopal Church in MARY.
land. and Provost of the University of MARYLAND.
who departed th, life yesterday at about quarter
past o'clock. z. NJ The meekness with which this
distinguished divine bore his high faculties, had en-
deared him in peculiar manner to those whom Pro.
vidence had placed under bis pastoral charse.wlilst
his uniformly unassuming department, and upright
conduct rendered him the object ofprofound respect
on the part Of those with whom he acted in the gen.
eral intercourse of life. As the head of the Church
which he called to preside in this Diocese,
his loss will be long and deeply lalnented-as pr-
vate individual, those who were bound to him by the
closest ties of relationship and friendship, cam
alone form estimate Of the extent OF their beveav
ement.


The circumstances attending the death of this
estinabie and distinguished individual are such as
to render particular distressing. AS he was reur-
ming from Philade pha, where I've had been to assist
in the conservation of Bishop Onderdonk,in passing
over the Peninsula between the two bays the driver
of the coach in which he was, being intoxicated as
is supposed. attempted to pass another carriage and
upset the coach, by which means several OF the pas
sensers were severely injured, and among Others
Bishop KEMP received the hurt, which has terminal
ed in his death.


Scarcely day passes that we do not hear some
new account OF the outrageous conduct Of Coach
men, and their careless driving. 1t is high time
that the strong arm Of the law should interpose, aud
punish in an exemplary manner these offenders
against public safety.

the senate chamber for the purpose of Gaming menu
Der, Tor daring to question the proprlety OF hls
measures, say, If he would commit this bold viu-
lence when merely general. what would he not do,
as president OF the United States, as commander-ln
chief Of the army and navy. Oh Pennsylvanlans
be warned. Let not your blind zeal overcome the
prudence for which you have been long famed
Force not the deslinies ot your now happy, pros
porous and peaceful country into the hands Of an
incorporate Hotspur Our present pilot. is wise,
prudent, experienced, and patriotic. Why, then
should you wish a change?


Why should you wish to assign to Gen. Jackson
the important duties Of the presidency, when his
own bographer asserts. that he resigned civil sta
tons that required only moderate talents, from
conscious inability to perform the dutle. OF them


NESTOR.

full articles.article:
From the .N'e1p- Orleans .lrgus, Sept 28.


The following is extract of letter addressed
to the editor Of the Argus, containing statement Of
The late bloody affair, near Natchez, by party
from Alexandria, via Eapde =


Concordia, Sept. "a, 1927,


Dear Sir 81 was invited by Dr. Maddox. not
long since, to interview without the limits Of the
State. met him at Natchez, on the 18th instant


on the 18th, was challenged by him. appointed
the 9th for the day, and the first sand beach above
Natchez, on the Mississippi side, for the place o.
our meeting. We met exchanged two shots with
out effect, and made friends. Myself and my tnenq'
Major NV Whortcr, and my surgeon DR.. Cuney,
were invited by DR.. Maddox and his friend, Col
Crane, and surgeon, Mr. Denny, to the Wooas'
where his friends, who were excluded from the
held, were stationed, to take some refreshment
when about half way, we were met by my irenas,
Gen. Cuney, Mr.. James Bowie, and my brother VINO
had accompanied me from Red River, and VINO
were also excluded from the field, and had taken
their station in the woods about two huadrec yaros
from the field. Gen. Quincy, on meeting us. enqur.
ed of me how the affair had been settled toa
him that Dir. Maddox and myself had exchanged
two shots and made friends Eic then turned to Col.
Crane who was near me, and observed to hun, lhas
there was difference between them, and they l@a
better return to the ground and settle it. as Docof
Maddox and myself had done DR.. Cuney ana my,
self nerposed, and stated to the General, tha ha'
not the time place ior the adjustment OF lheli
difference the General ilnnediatey acqmesceo
and his brother had turned to leave him, wheh
Crane, without replying to Gen. Cuney, or sayilS
one word, 1red pistol at him, which ne cari'eu
in his hand, but without effect. then steppeu
back one OF two PAGES, when Crane drew from ND >
belt another pistol, fred it and wounded Geneiai
Cuney in his thigh he expired in about fifteen nm
utes. As Crane presented his second pistol, uen.
Cuney placed his hand upon the breach OF his pu;
did not draw until he had received Cranes second
fire, and as he was falling. Gen, Cuney did nos
will state on the authority of DR.. Hunt. of Natchez


that Crane had said to his friends in Natchez' tha


# Gen Quincy made his appearance on the ground
he, Crane, would kill hm-and that at all events
he intended to kill him the first opportunity-ano
we'll has he kept his promise Mr.. Denny has slne'
informed me that Crane had made the same dee'S

full articles.headline: PEoPLE OF COLOR.
full articles.article:
1t will be gratifying the friends Of freedom to
learn that the people Of coloy held by the society Of
Friends in North Carolina, are all in fair way to
be placed in free governments. Since the number
sent out last year, the meeting has received donations
from this continent, to the amount Of nearly fys
thousand dollars, in addition to two Thousand dol
lars raised by themselves. We also learn that q
draft to considerable amount has been received
from they early Meeting of the Society Of Friends
in London. to assist them in the noble undertaking.
The present prospect is, that in the course Of year
or two more, 6etWeen one and f1co thousand persons
will be placed in situation to enjoy their unaena-
ole righs We understand that the principal part
Of them will go to Africa and st. Domingo.


Nat. Hist

full articles.headline: GEN. JACKSON & CON. DECATUR.
full articles.article:
red between these gentlemen some years ago, near
the door of the y. 5. Senate Chamber. As have
derived the particulars from an authentic source,
shall take the liberty Of submlttn, them TO the con-
sderatlon of the public


The extraordinary measures of Gen. Jackson
during the continuance Of the Seminole war; not
only elected deep and loud complaints from the
public. but attracted the notice of Congress. The
subject was broush before the House Of Represen-
tatives by Mr Clay, the present distinguished Sc
cretary of State. He animadverted on the Gene
ral's disregard of orders, well as of legal and
constitutional restraint, with degree Of boldness |
and eoqaence which even surpassed all his prevlcas
efforts.


The Generals conduct was also made subject
of inquiry in the Senate. In this investigation Mr.
Leacock and Roberts, of this state. and Mr.. Eppes,
Of Va. took an active part The GeNeral COM
planned with much bitterness. Of the course pur
sued by all these gentlemen and threatened to cut
off their ears. He selected, however, Mr. Eppes,
the sonnaw of the patriot Jefferson, as the part
cuar object of his vengeance. and swUre, with his
usual profanity, that he would chastise him in the
midst Of the body in which his injurious remarks
had been made. This report reached the Of
the gallant Decatur. lie considered it, however,
as Of those idle declarations which men Of intem-
perae passions not unfrequently make, without any
intention of putting into execution.


The last of the session, the senate have even
ing sitting for the purpose of receiving messages
from the President. On this occasion the Commo-
dore conducted Mrs. Decatur to the brick capitol,
to witness the ceremony of the adjournment of the
Senate. As they passed through SIN III antl-room
to the door OF the Senate chamber, about nine
O'Clock at night, they with surprise, Gen. Jack
son, with his two aids de-camp walking backwards
and Forwards appearing under the Influence Of
great excitement. so soon as he conducted Mrs.
Decatur to a seat in the lobby he returned and ask
cd of al IS ph.thp pot ttIIp at
Gen. Jackson intended to attack Mr.. Eppes in the
Senate chamber The reply was, such is the Gene
rails intention, and such ls the object Of his visit 10
the capitol this noor. He added further that it
altogether impossible tor any one to alter his de-
termination.


Decatur then turned to Gen. jackson, and OBJ
served. with that giayc, aud firm tone for which he
was so remarkable : - have Just learned, sir,
with deep regret that the object Of your visit to the
capitol, at this late hour. is to chastse Mr.. Eppes
III the senate cha,nher.''


The Geueral reyle l. with a voice faulterng with
passion. ..yps, str, ihe d-n'd rascal has injured
nv reputation. and will be avenged of him thi-
evening" will cane him in the senate chamber--]
will teach the scoundrel TO impeach my conduct, o
to call in question the propriety Of my measures


= hem replied The gallant Cominolore. !" yol
are AN nndone man-your fame will be shipwrecket
and the nation dlssraeed. For Gods sake be di
yerted from your purpnses-the pers0ns OF Our -,
nators are sacred. when engaged in their ,leibera
tons, and It IS our duty 10 protect and Not to assa
them.''


Whilst Decatur was thus earnestly rendering hi
advice. jackson hastily interrupted him altn th
following remark :. | have made il rue IN life
sir. 10 be restnged OF all insults, and l not
to be diverted from my purposes. BY the eterna
Cd | viii! enter the senate chamber and No. Il,
Id rascal"


Decatur slapped his hands together in hi, own p'
,,It b,,u
ter that door. sr, miess il be my teal body!


Jackson stepped back his lips compressed, an
his face pallid with anger ; he eyed in silence II
gallant spirit opposed to him for the space of half
minute. He remarked, :. Decatur regard YOU
friend, and respect you gallant officer, b
you must not, charge YOU interfere in my designs


The Cummo,lnre replied 81 recprocate yu
obliging expressions, but my friendship for YOU
nv admiration Of your gallant exploits, cannot
compared with the estimation in which hold II
country she Shall never be dis sraced while it is
my pnwes to prevent it,


witnessing the lnhexib,e determination of Dec
tur, the General lowered his tone of violence, al
intreated in his that there should be no int
ference with his purposes" General jackson
sal, Decatur. +" | respect the feelings of IA sodt
but the coa.se which you have taken in this AHA
canaot receive the sanction of any one wiio
judgement is free from the influence Of passion
must therefore, again lntreat of you. to abanl
your present rash aud ncensiderae intentions y


jackson gave Decatur familiar slap on


shoulder; and observed .. you a gallant solli


! know you would not advise inc to any cna


which is incompatible with the honor Of d so|,ligY


The truth Of Ne above anecdntc can he sustain


BY the most positive and unimneachabe testimo


The galant the lelr'ut,c, tne high minded Dpca


himself has detailed the circumstances to seve


highly respectable gentlemen in this state.


detail was made at time when no one in his sen


eyer supposed General Jackson wonld he brou

.1nother Ballot.--A balloting for President, took

MANUFACTURES IN TIE SOUTH.
full articles.article:
TtETsgS SEsxslA& IL NJ.


MANUFACTURES IN THE SOUTH.
Tie capacity of the Southern states for manufac-
turing their great staple is no longer IA matter OF
speculation. Practical experiment has demonstrated,
not only their capacity TO manufacture, but to man
ufacture their own staple at cheaper rate than IN
any part of the Union Last February. year,
accompanied most intelligent Tennessee planter
from Ptisburg to Nashville, Mr.. Nightingale, Tor
merly of Rhode Island. He was then taking with
him .foreman', from Providence, Rhode island, to
superntend his cotton factory. This factory IS To-
Gated in Maury county, Tennessee. The machine
ry is propelled by never failing. and never fseez,
ing water power. The entire abour is performed
BY slaves. Mr. Nightingale now supplies a large
portion OF Tennessee and North Alabama with coarse
cotton goods. His profits upon his capital are said
to be quadrupe the profits Of the cotton grower.
What, then, but enterprise, is wanting to Introduce
the manufacture of cotton. largely the Southern
states, from Maryland to Loulsiana-for the follow
III. reasons


LIST. he capacity of the slave to manufacture
is demonstrated by the test Of practical expert
nent.

also evident. to anv one who will reflect, that the

err


4. The superior mildness Of the climate. not
only facilitates the operation of the spindle and
the loom, but arrests hand of winter which
binds the Northern water power IN letters o
ice.

portant. the expenee Of sending off the raw materi
